article:
More than one million children are homeless in the United States.  To highlight the problem, 12-year-old Zach Bonner walked across the southeastern United States, a 1,900 kilometer journey to bring attention to the plight  of homeless children. "I think it's ridiculous that there's any child that doesn't have a  _  in this country," Zach explains. He traveled from Florida to Washington, D.C. where he told an audience that child homelessness in America was real."It still   _  me the amount of people still today who don't   _  this problem even exists. And the truth is, not only does it exist, but it's getting worse," he stressed. Zach says the problem has several   _  . "Because of the economic crisis, people lose their jobs and homes, and 35 _ , children become homeless. Sometimes, the families are abusive toward the child and they   run away  ."
               Zach did the walk between his studies.  It took him three years to   _   his walk, which he began when he was only eight years old.  He   _   20 kilometers a day.  No matter how   _   he got, Zach says he felt he had to   _  walking. Along the way, Zach visited homeless   _    , helping plant the gardens - all kinds of stuff, "just getting to play with the kids," he says, "  _   making at least one day of their life better."
Zach has a long   _  of helping others.  When he was six, a powerful hurricane   _  parts of his home state of Florida.  To help people who had no food or water, he   _   around his neighborhood with a little red wagon,   _   for donations of bottled water, personal hygiene products and other   _  . Zach has received awards for his   _   service, including one from President George W. Bush in 2006. 
Next year he plans to   put on   his walking shoes again for homeless kids. This   _   would be almost twice as long -- from Tampa, Florida to Los Angeles, California.
